title: Boris Johnson warns French PM Brexit cannot be delayed
text:
Boris Johnson phoned a number of EU state leaders including Emmanuel Macron over the weekend

(Picture: Backgrid; Getty)

Boris Johnson has reportedly warned the French president against being lulled into thinking Brexit will be delayed past October 31.

The Prime Minister spent the weekend speaking to leaders of EU states including Emmanuel Macron, after making proposals for a new deal to secure Britain’s exit from the bloc.

The latest offer has been met with a mixed reception from the EU, and legislation passed by opposition MPs compels him to send a letter requesting an extension to the October 31 deadline if no deal is agreed.

Mr Johnson has continued to insist Brexit will happen by then ‘come what may’.

A senior Downing Street official said EU leaders would be making a ‘historic misunderstanding’ to believe the opposition legislation could prevent a no-deal Brexit.

The official said the UK could still leave if the European Commission does not budge.

President Macron has generally taken a firm stance against further delays to Brexit (Picture: BEST IMAGE / BACKGRID)

The PM was said to have told Mr Macron it was the final chance to secure a deal, and that the EU must match the compromises the UK has made.

During their call on Sunday, Mr Johnson reportedly said he wanted to reach an agreement acceptable to both sides and that his new offer had the support of MPs, unlike Theresa May’s deal.

Mr Macron told the PM he has until the end of the week to find a way out of the logjam with EU negotiators, according to a French official cited by The Guardian.

The Government may also now consider publishing the full legal text of the offer, which has only been shared confidentially with Brussels, if it is deemed helpful to the negotiations.

The official said: ‘This is the chance to get a deal done: a deal that is backed by parliamentarians and a deal which involves compromise on all sides.

‘The UK has made a big, important offer but it’s time for the Commission to show a willingness to compromise too. If not the UK will leave with no deal.

‘The surrender act and its authors are undermining negotiations, but if EU leaders are betting that it will prevent no-deal, that would be a historic misunderstanding.’

description: The PM reportedly said the final chance for a deal is now, despite a law aimed at blocking no-deal.
